channel.title: Compiling/running server using Shell scripting
channel.description:
Difficulty: 3/10 Requirements: An application that handles shell scripts (i.e. Terminal.app located in your utilities folder.)
We're going start this tutorial off with an explanation of shell script. Shell is the equivalent of the command prompt for mac. It's remotely related to java, in that it has variables, if-then/if-then-else statements, do-while statements, and input/output. This script will contain variables, input reading, output, and if-then-else statement.
Scripts are saved with the .sh file extension and can be edited outside of terminal, or whatever your using.
So finally, we'll get started with the actual tutorial. So open up TextEdit, or anything that can edit shell scripts, and paste this: [code]#!/bin/sh
# Compiler.sh # Created by TheChubbyBunny @ Moparscape forums #
printf "Please specify your server's path:"
read MYPATH
echo "your server is located in $MYPATH" #just basically a test to see if it's reading the input
cd $MYPATH
printf "Please specify an action: 'compile', 'run', or 'both':"
read ACTION
if [ "$ACTION" = "compile" ] ; then
javac *.java
echo "compiling server..."
elif [ "$ACTION" = "run" ] ; then
java -Xmx256m server
echo "running server..."
elif [ "$ACTION" == "both" ] ; then
javac *.java java -Xmx256m server
echo "compiling and running server..." else
echo "Error in specifying an action, please re-execute the script"
fi[/code]
Save it as compiler.sh, and [B][U]SAVE IT IN YOUR HOME FOLDER, OTHERWISE IT WILL NOT WORK.[/B][/U] Well, just make sure the script is in your home folder.
Now open up Terminal or whatever, and type this:
[code]chmod +x compiler.sh[/code]
This makes the script executable Now type this:
[code]./compiler.sh[/code]
That command will run the script.
Here's a screenshot of what it will look like:
[IMG]http://i266.photobucket.com/albums/ii280/runegay/Picture1-1.png[/img]
Here's some pointers: - If you don't type compile, run, or both right, the script will not be ineffect anymore, I can't do anything about that as far as I know - Once you specify an action (Input compile, run, or both) you'll have to re-execute the script to do another one, again, I can't help it
Credits: Me People at Macrumors programming forums
That's it, reply if you need any help.
